message_1: A spaceship is traveling at 90% the speed of light toward a planet with a strong gravitational field. According to the planet's clock, one hour has passed while the spaceship was in transit. How much time has passed on the spaceship? (Assuming the gravitational time dilation effect due to the planet's gravitational field is negligible).
message_2:
To solve this problem, we need to use the concept of time dilation in special relativity. Time dilation occurs when an object is moving at a significant fraction of the speed of light relative to an observer. The equation for time dilation is:

Δt' = Δt / √(1 - v²/c²)

where:
Δt' is the time interval experienced by the moving object (the spaceship in this case)
Δt is the time interval experienced by the observer at rest (the planet's clock)
v is the relative velocity of the moving object (90% the speed of light)
c is the speed of light

We are given that Δt = 1 hour and v = 0.9c. Plugging these values into the equation, we get:

Δt' = 1 hour / √(1 - (0.9c)²/c²)

Δt' = 1 hour / √(1 - 0.81)

Δt' = 1 hour / √(0.19)

Δt' ≈ 1 hour / 0.4359

Δt' ≈ 2.294 hours

So, approximately 2.294 hours have passed on the spaceship according to its own clock.
